OBSERVATOIRE POUR LE DROIT A LA DIFFERENCE • Final training on intersectionality for the benefits of the Observatory’s partners, 19th-20th February 2021 in Medenine: o 24 participants in total (15 women, 9 men, 14 NGO’s) // trainer: Cyrine Hammemi.
• Sensitization campaigns planning with partners of the O3DT: Following the intersectionality trainings aimed at building the capacities of the O3DT partners in theoretical and technical notions related to intersectional activism, reflection workshops on sensitization messages took place with the latter. The workshops, facilitated by Cyrine (O3DT), followed a methodology consisting on identifying the expectations and objectives of associations related to campaigns to be conducted with O3DT. After the identification process, targets and clear activities were transcribed. See concept note and report annexed. o 6 workshops took place in: Bizerte, Kef, Tunis, Kairouan, Sousse and Medenine. o February 6, 2021: Bizerte: 9 associations: ADD-We love Bizerte-Changers-Merset-LTDH-JCI-IBSAR-Club de presse-Canal Bizerte. 18 participants: 10 women and 8 men. o February 10, 2021 : Kef, Jendouba, Beja: 10 associations: ADD-AFR- Ligue de droits politique et sociale de la femme- Renouvellement et appartenance-Fnara- AVJB- joussour citoyenneté-DAMJ-Afp Kef-association béja. 21 participants : 18 women and 3 men. o February 12, 2021:Tunis:13 associations: ADD-Chapitre II-Talaki-BYLHWEM-Radiocean-MRG-Taqallam-ATP+-MAWJOUDIN-ADLI-UDD-ATDDE-NOT4TRADE. 21 participants: 12 women and 9 men. o February 16, 2021:Kairouan: 5 associations: ADD-DAD-UNFTK-We love Kairouan. 12 participants: 9 women and 3 men. o February 21, 2021:Tozeur-Gafsa-Sidi Bouzid-Médenine-Kébili: 12 associations: voix du sud-ADESM-NVZ-ATAC-MADA-CUAM-Musaique-ATUDE-ACL-AJDM-ADDCI-ADD. 18 participants: 10 women and 8 men. o February 27, 2021: Sousse-Sfax-Gabès-Kasserine-Mahdia-Sidi Bouzid-Nabeul :13 associations : ADD-FDD-DAMJ-Oueshma-Mouwatinet-We love Sousse-Danseurs sud-7e dimension-Tigar-ATCA-ATEG-la Tunisie que nous voulons-MRG. 21 participants: 14 women and 7 men.
• Parliamentary day on the 24th of March: o Kick off of the series of workshops of exchange with deputies in collaboration with MRG. o General objective of the workshop:Participative work in order to address the issue of the harmonization of the legislation related to the right to difference on three levels: 1. With the constitution of 2014, 2. With the conventions and treaties duly ratified (global or regional), 3. Between the texts that have the same legal value (contradictory laws).
o First event: Themes: racial discrimination, handicap and article 230 –condition of Queer people in Tunisia. Present: 14 NGOs – 20 journalists, Present parliamentary assistants: 2. - Present deputies:  Ms. Jamila Ksiksi – Nahdha  Mr. Hatem Mliki – QalbTounes  Mr. Moustapha ben Ahmed – TahyaTounes
• Awareness raising videos: o Release of the call of service. o Selection of two contractors: Cinema professionals according to a technical and artistic grill. o Release of the first Video on the 8th of March: International women’s day. o Link: https://www.facebook.com/2162835327065900/videos/745461739289008 o Data: Number of views 8400, reactions 113, shares 46.
• Discrimination cases documented between January-March 2021: o Poles coordinators documented 114 cases of discrimination spread out in the following regions:  North-East: 21.  North-West: 4.  Center-Est: 35.  Center-West:0.  South-East: 9.  South-West: 1.
MINORITY RIGHTS GROUP INTERNATIONAL • Some PADs continued the documentation of cases of discrimination. During this period, we received 42 cases of discrimination (28 based on SOGIESC and 14 cases against sub-Saharan migrants). • Our pool of lawyers provided 5 legal consultancies to Sub-Saharan migrants and defended 4 cases on behalf of a person with disabilities, a non-Muslim, a migrant and a Black Tunisian. Furthermore, a Sub-Saharan woman was assisted in the legal procedures to get financial reparation. • A consultant was recruited in February to analyse the cases of discrimination we collected in 2020. The report, available in Arabic and French, was launched in a webinar on the 21st of March, International Day against Racial Discrimination. The webinar was moderated by MRG MENA Coordinator with the presence of the author of the report in addition to a spokesperson of the Sub-Saharan migrants in Tunisia and a spokesperson of the LGBTQI+ community from our Points Anti-Discrimination Network, respectively “By-Lhwem” and “Damj”. • A meeting with our pool of lawyers and the Baha’i organization “Unity in Diversity” was held to discuss potential strategies for advocacy. A press conference was held on the 16th of March in partnership with them and the Observatory to announce that a case was filed by the Baha’i community against the government because of accusation of blasphemy. • In February, MRG organised a 2-week field visit to the South of Tunisia to investigate issues of racism including changinglast names referring to slavery. • In March, the MENA Coordinator spoke about our work regarding the fight against racial discrimination at a panel organised by the OHCHR. • On 26th and 27th March, MRG and Damj organised the first lawyers’ training on SOGIESC training. 14 lawyers (10 women and 4 men) in addition to civil society organisations representatives. • 19 trainees (14 women, 4 men and 1 non-binary) are taking the French version of the online class on “Journalism and Diversity in the Media). 18 participants (11 women, 5 men and 2 non-binary) are taking the Arabic version of the course. • During the three last months, our Facebook page “Points Anti-Discrimination” gained 700 new likes which led to more public engagement with our posts.
